history.content: make a string lowercase then capitalise the first letter

This function takes a string from the Inputs.String input, converts it to lowercase, and then capitalizes the first letter. If the input string is empty, the function will not perform any action. The result is then sent to the Outputs.CapitalizedString output. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the process, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error details and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
make a string lowercase then capitalise the first letter

This function takes a string from the Inputs.String input, converts it to lowercase, and then capitalizes the first letter. If the input string is empty, the function will not perform any action. The result is then sent to the Outputs.CapitalizedString output. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the process, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error details and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Format a date input as "Today at HH:MM" or "Yesterday at HH:MM" or "Tues 20 Oct 2023 at HH:MM"

This function takes a date input and formats it in a human-readable way. The function accepts a date through the Inputs.DateInput and formats it as "Today at HH:MM" if the date is today, "Yesterday at HH:MM" if the date was yesterday, or "Day DD Month YYYY at HH:MM" for any other date. The function uses the JavaScript Date object to get the day, date, month, and year, and formats the hours and minutes with leading zeros if necessary. If the function succeeds, it sends the formatted date to the Outputs.FormattedDate and triggers the Outputs.Success signal. If there is an error, it sends the error to the Outputs.error and triggers the Outputs.Failure signal.
Call this n8n endpoint with parameters 'email' and 'rootDomain' http://n8n.localhost/webhook-test/fe59eb69-eccf-42f1-90b3-4ffc0c875a5e

This function takes Inputs.Email and Inputs.RootDomain as inputs, constructs a URL with these parameters, and makes a GET request to a specified n8n endpoint. If the request is successful, it sends the response data to the Outputs.ResponseData output and triggers the Outputs.Success signal. If the request fails, it sends the error to the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure signal. It's important to note that the function requires both 'Email' and 'RootDomain' to be provided. If either of these inputs is missing, the function will throw an error.

comments.text:
Set this object with the same properties that you want to work with in your n8n workflow.

For example setting a property 'email' (string) here will be received on the n8n side as ${'Webhook'}.item.json.body.email
Replace the template input properties with whatever you need for the Create New Object node ahead

If you want to get error responses using 'Respond to webhook' nodes in n8n, use 'JSON' response type and create an object with 'code': 500 or any integer that's not 200. 

If this core component detects the 'code' property of the response and it's anything other than 200 or undefined, it'll output the Failed signal and error output

Don't forget to set the root domain of your n8n instance, the webhook id to use for this template copy, and whether this is a test workflow run or not. 

Edit the 'n8n root domain' String node inside the core component to not have to re-type it every time in the template copy.

comments.text:
Input array should be like:

[
    { 
    "itemText": "value",
    "textColour": "value" ,
    "itemIcon": "value",
    "itemId": "value'
    }
]

The itemIcon field should be the raw name of a Google Material icon like user_add

The itemId should be a random unique id
Use the component children node to allow you to add a title or whatever to the top of your list of dropdown items like 'User menu' or something

history.content: Convert an image url into a base64 png string

This function takes an image URL from the Inputs.ImageUrl input, fetches the image, and converts it into a Blob. It then reads the Blob as a base64 string using a FileReader. The base64 string is then outputted through the Outputs.Base64String output. If the process is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If an error occurs at any point during the process, the error is outputted through the Outputs.error output and the Outputs.Failure output signal is triggered.

roots.label: Sign Up User to Brevo List

history.content: Make a call to Brevo to sign a user up to a list

This function makes a call to the Brevo API to sign a user up to a specified list. It requires Inputs.ApiKey, Inputs.Email, and Inputs.ListId as inputs. The function checks for the validity of these inputs and constructs a request to the Brevo API. If the request is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal; otherwise, it captures the error and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. It is important to ensure that the API key, email, and list ID are valid before making the API call, as the function will throw errors if any of these inputs are missing or incorrect.
Use a free QR code generator API to generate a QR code from an input URL

This function generates a QR code from a given URL. It takes Inputs.URL and Inputs.QRCodeSize as inputs. The function uses the QR Server API to create a QR code of the specified size for the provided URL. The QR code is returned as an image, which is then converted into a blob and subsequently into a URL that can be used to display the image. If the QR code is successfully generated, the function outputs the image URL through Outputs.QRCodeImage and triggers the Outputs.Success signal. If there is an error during the process, the function outputs the error through Outputs.error and triggers the Outputs.Failure signal.
Output a URLencoded url from an input url

This function takes a URL and encodes it into a URL-safe format. It takes Inputs.URL as an input, checks if it's valid, and then uses the encodeURIComponent function to encode the URL. The encoded URL is then set as the Outputs.EncodedURL. If the encoding is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the encoding process, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Output a URLencoded url from an input url

This function takes a URL and encodes it into a URL-safe format. It takes Inputs.URL as an input, checks if it's valid, and then uses the encodeURIComponent function to encode the URL. The encoded URL is then set as the Outputs.EncodedURL. If the encoding is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the encoding process, it sets the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

history.content: Output the current window width, which changes as the window is resized

This function listens to the window resize event and outputs the current window width. When the window is resized, it retrieves the current window width using the 'innerWidth' property of the 'window' object, or the 'clientWidth' property of the 'documentElement' or 'body' if 'innerWidth' is not available. The current window width is then assigned to the Outputs.WindowWidth output.

roots.label: Output Current Date and Time in ISO Format

history.content: Output today's date and time in ISO format

This function retrieves the current date and time, converts it to ISO format, and outputs it. It first creates a new Date object to get the current date and time. Then, it converts this date and time to an ISO format string using the toISOString() method. The ISO formatted date and time is then set as the Outputs.ISODateTime output. Finally, the function signals success by triggering the Outputs.Success output signal.

roots.label: Check If Date Is Before Current Date

history.content: Check if an input ISO date time is less than the current date at 00:00 in the morning

This function checks if an input ISO date time is less than the current date at 00:00 in the morning. It takes an Inputs.ISODateTime as input, converts it to a Date object, and checks if it's a valid date. If it's not, it throws an error. It then gets the current date, sets the time to 00:00, and compares the input date to the current date. If the input date is before the current date, it sets the Outputs.IsBefore output to true and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If the input date is not before the current date, it sets the Outputs.IsBefore output to false and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

comments.text:
Set this object with the same properties that you want to work with in your n8n workflow.

For example setting a property 'email' (string) here will be received on the n8n side as ${'Webhook'}.item.json.body.email
Replace the template input properties with whatever you need for the Create New Object node ahead

If you want to get error responses using 'Respond to webhook' nodes in n8n, use 'JSON' response type and create an object with 'code': 500 or any integer that's not 200. 

If this core component detects the 'code' property of the response and it's anything other than 200 or undefined, it'll output the Failed signal and error output

Don't forget to set the root domain of your n8n instance, the webhook id to use for this template copy, and whether this is a test workflow run or not. 

Edit the 'n8n root domain' String node inside the core component to not have to re-type it every time in the template copy.
Go directly to main if signed in

roots.label: Filter community labels and share codes

history.content: Filter an input array and output only objects where the 'theme' string field value can be found in another input array of objects (in the 'Value' field)

This function filters an input array to output only those objects where the 'theme' string field value is present in another input array of objects (specifically in the 'Value' field). It takes Inputs.InputArray and Inputs.FilterArray as inputs, checks if they are valid arrays, and extracts the 'Value' field from the Inputs.FilterArray. The function then filters the Inputs.InputArray based on the 'theme' field and outputs the results through Outputs.FilteredResults. It's important to ensure that both input arrays are provided and valid; otherwise, the function will trigger the Outputs.Failure output signal. Additionally, if the filtering is successful, it will trigger the Outputs.Success output signal.
